scope_of_work.problem: Main water meters are read at the end of every month and the sprinkler supply meter is not functioning. Following investigation and testing the sprinkler tank meter was found to have failed and requires replacement

scope_of_work.problem: The NHB HV Control System has no essential spares for 'ready use' in the event of an unforeseen issue or breakdown.
scope_of_work.scope:
Supply and secure site storage of the following essential spares for 'ready use' in the event of an unforeseen issue or breakdown on the NHB HV Control System.

1. Intelisys base box
2. I-CR-R
3. Inteligen basebox
4. Inteli I/O 8/8
5. 6x Finder single pole relays
scope_of_work.justification: The NHB HV Control System specialist (ECS) has strongly recommended a small list of essential spares for 'ready use' due to expected long lead-times (3-weeks+).
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: Inability to resolve the most commonly anticipated HV Control System fault scenarios in a timely manner, subsequently exposing the site critical load to unnecessary risk for extended periods (3-weeks+).

scope_of_work.problem: Following Generator 2 routine monthly runs the unit had to be shut down immediately due to excessive noise. After investigation no damage was found to any valves, pistons or liners, however there was an unusual high build up of carbon. We found that Cylinder B1 Injector had seized and that there was damage to A Bank turbocharger. A major overhaul is required. The unit remains off-line until repairs are complete
scope_of_work.scope:
Following specialist investigation the following repairs are required.
OPTION 2 is to replace Turbocharger. Replace seized injector with new unit only and overhaul other 11 injectors. Replace Oil & Filters.
scope_of_work.justification: Ph1 Generators provide power to the Ph1 DC Building Services in the event of a Mains Fail

project_name: UPM-Kyndryl Warwick - Install and commision 3 x Intercom in DC Tigertrap
status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Brando Dooley DDS

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem: The 3 analogue intercoms currently in place within the Tigertrap PH1 do not contact the Security office
scope_of_work.scope:
3no. intercoms will be supplied and installed within the Tiger Trap to replace the existing end of life analogue versions already in situ. Replacement IP cabling will be installed from the intercom locations back to the existing intercom switch located in the security rack within the machine room.
The answering station in the security office will be reconfigured to accept calls from the 3no. new intercoms which will therefore total 6no. intercoms connected across the site.
scope_of_work.justification: Picked up on a security audit, if an incident was to happen within the tigertrap there was no facility to contact security direct. With new intercoms security can be contacted within the trigertrap by the user or either side of the trap by a member of staff passing by if for instance the user had collapsed.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: No way of contacting security in the event of an incident, possibly delaying in receiving medical help in the event of an incident.

status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Flo Hodkiewicz

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem:
On inspection it could be seen that although most of the Fan Section of the cooling tower is constructed 
from stainless steel, the end wall closest to the adjoining tower is powder coated steel. The powder coating has failed and corrosion is evident on the exposed steelwork. It is therefore 
recommended to repair these areas using epoxy paint, to help stop contamination with the cooling tower.
scope_of_work.scope:
• Specialist contractor to carry out pre-chlorination of the cooling tower prior to works beginning
• Lay tarpaulin over the top of the Cooling Tower and secure in place
• Using Access Hatches at low level, gain access to the interior of the cooling tower.
• Prepare all accessible steel surfaces by removing all paint and corrosion products
• Clean out Cooling Tower following this task and wash the surfaces of the steel with water to remove 
any salt deposits
• Apply primer for use with weathered steel and allow to cure
• Apply first coat of paint and allow to cure overnight using heaters to ensure sufficient curing
• Apply second coat of paint and allow to cure
• Remove taurpaulin
• Post disinfection of the cooling tower
• Clean up site and provide Job Completion certificate to nominated site contact.
scope_of_work.justification:
Corrosion is the breakdown of metal and naturally occurs when a metal comes into contact with water. In cooling tower systems, the chance of corrosion is particularly high due to the chemicals used in water treatment and the high concentration of electrolytes in the water due to evaporation. Additionally, water corrosivity increases with high conductivity in cooling tower water since corrosion is an electrochemical process by nature.

Corrosion can cause serious problems in a cooling tower, including:

Debris: Corrosion can result in metal debris entering the water system, contaminating the water, blocking pipes and causing inefficient cooling processes. 
Leaks: Corroded metal can create small holes within the system, exposing the closed water system to the outside. This can result in water leaking from the cooling tower or biological contaminants entering the system.
Equipment damage: Corrosion can cause serious damage to a cooling tower’s equipment, leading to costly downtime and repair and replacement fees.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect:
Corrosion is the breakdown of metal and naturally occurs when a metal comes into contact with water. In cooling tower systems, the chance of corrosion is particularly high due to the chemicals used in water treatment and the high concentration of electrolytes in the water due to evaporation. Additionally, water corrosivity increases with high conductivity in cooling tower water since corrosion is an electrochemical process by nature.

Corrosion can cause serious problems in a cooling tower, including:

Debris: Corrosion can result in metal debris entering the water system, contaminating the water, blocking pipes and causing inefficient cooling processes. 
Leaks: Corroded metal can create small holes within the system, exposing the closed water system to the outside. This can result in water leaking from the cooling tower or biological contaminants entering the system.
Equipment damage: Corrosion can cause serious damage to a cooling tower’s equipment, leading to costly downtime and repair and replacement fees.

project_name: UPM-Replacement of VESDA system filters - (3 Year Cycle)
status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):billing completed by Marge Hills (2):offer approved by Marge Hills (3):offer submitted by Marge Hills (4):work in progress by Marge Hills

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem: The NHB VESDA (Very Early Smoke Detection Apparatus) System filters are 3yrs old and due for replacement.
scope_of_work.scope: Replacement of all VESDA System filters at NHB DC. 70 filter cartridges in total.
scope_of_work.justification: This is a specialist recommendation to ensure the VESDA Systems remain fully compliant and operational.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: Not replacing the VESDA filters increases the potential for the System to initiate spurious alarms or to no longer detect real smoke events as designed.
